author: Octavio Ramos
title: Halloween 2015: McCall’s Haunted Farm
text:
Play In 2013, Duke City Local covered McCall's Haunted Farm in Moriarty. Duke City Local The back-story for this haunted attraction is bleak. The story goes that the McCall family owned a stretch of land for several hundred years in Moriarty, New Mexico. When the State Highway Department build an interstate right through the farm, Mr. McCall watched as his farm fell into ruin. Despondent and crazed, McCall slaughtered his wife and children. Although there were police investigations, there was no evidence that McCall has killed his family. When the investigations died down, there were rumors that McCall had continued his murderous ways, this time butchering motorists who passed by his farm. When investigators returned, they did find the skeletal remains of many missing tourists, but McCall himself was never found.
McCall's Haunted Farm With autumn just around the corner McCall’s Haunted Farm in Moriarty, New Mexico, is ready to create some scares for the unwary.
McCall’s Haunted Farm [ https://www.facebook.com/mccallshauntedfarm] will be open on Fridays (7–10 p.m.) and Saturdays (7–10 p.m.) starting on weekend of October 2–3 and ending on the weekend of October 30–31. Ticket sales onsite start at 6:15 p.m. Get tickets online at Ticketleap . Ticket prices vary, depending on the weekend (visit the site and click on the “tickets” link for details. In general, it costs $4.95 for general admission to the farm and as much as $47.95 for a VIP+ Prime Time pass.
For 2015, McCall’s Haunted Farm offers three principal attractions. The first is “The Haunted Cornfield,” which is supposedly haunted by the many victims of McCall. Can you keep your sanity and make it out alive?
The second is “The Haunted Barn,” the McCall family butcher shop, which is filled with crazed characters waiting to terrify those willing to enter their realm.
The third is the “Zombie Hunt,” where participants get to shoot live zombies. Participants hop on board a custom-build post-apocalyptic ride fitted with paintball guns. Shoot glowing paintballs at the live zombies. The entry fee includes 100 paintballs for each participant.
McCall’s Haunted Farm is recommended to those who are at a minimum 13 years old. The attraction is about a one-hour drive from Albuquerque. The attraction has implemented a new queue line system to cut down on the long lines many participants experienced in previous years.
To get to McCall’s Farm take I-40 east of Albuquerque and take exit 196 near Moriarty. Travel north over the overpass and turn west (the first left) onto Abrahames Road. Proceed west on this road and you will see the farm on the right side of the road. The attraction will set out signs along the route to facilitate travel.
There’s an all-day pass available, at it covers daytime activities , which include a hayride to the pumpkin patch and access to activities such as the New Wee Wild West, Mechanical Bullrides, Chicken Shooting Arcade, and the 16-acre Corn Maze.
